Another fairly important point in consideration of the overall economics of the superphosphate industry in Australia is that in those States where agriculture and superphosphate usage have moved inland from the coastal areas, especially in Western Australia, it is urgently necessary to review the expansion of the manufacture of superphosphate in coastal locations.

Modern railway transport can cope with costs only by transporting bulk commodities in whole train loads from point to point. I instance bauxite and iron ore in Western Australia, and coal sent from Leigh Creek to Port Augusta where wonderfully efficient transport has been achieved by the railway system. That type of transport must be expanded if we are to make the railways pay. That is particularly important in Western Australia. Tt is of great importance to a manufacturer of superphosphate because, in the process of manufacture, onethird of the weight of the raw material, which is in fact water, need not be added at the point of manufacture but can be added inland, providing the amount to be manufactured at any one place is large enough to be economic.

The development of agriculture away from the coast and the concentration of the manufacture of superphosphate on the coast has led to several very undesirable circumstances in relation to agriculture generally. It has delayed the transport of superphosphate and necessitated the spread of deliveries over a long period. Consequently, it has led, through an increase in the usage of bulk superphosphate, to the establishment of rather uneconomic types of storage in the country. Worst of all, it has led to the application of superphosphate to save storage costs long before the break of the season. Experiments conducted, particularly in Western Australia, have shown that losses of efficiency of up to 50% can occur because of the premature application of superphosphate. As the Commonwealth Government is to pay a subsidy of up to $8 a ton in expanding the use of superphosphate, it has an interest in ensuring that it is used economically and not wasted. Because of premature application on a large scale in Western Australia, losses of efficiency are occurring.

In speaking in an earlier debate on this subject I regretted that the Commonwealth Government had decided not to pay a bounty on the use of rock phosphate on the ground that normally rock phosphate is not as efficient as superphosphate. That is true, but in some circumstances the use of rock phosphate is desirable. By not paying a bounty on the use of rock phosphate the Government did not save any money because the use of rock phosphate became no longer economic when compared with the use of superphosphate. Former users of rock phosphate simply transferred to superphosphate so that no bounty money was saved in that regard. It simply meant that there was an uneconomic transfer of what was in certain circumstances a desirable usage of one form of phosphate.

That development is of greater significance in the light of statements about biosuper in the twentieth annual report of CSIRO. I will quote from the report because it is of interest in considering the new development. The report states:

quote.para: At the Division of Soils, scientists have devised a novel way of turning low-grade rock phosphate into a more useful fertiliser which they have named 'biological superphosphate' or 'biosuper'. This fertiliser could be a suitable alternative to superphosphate in much of northern Australia where there are deposits of rock phosphate and where the cost of bringing in superphosphate is high. Biosuper is made by pelleting rock phosphate with sulphur and certain bacteria called thiobacilli. When biosuper is added to the soil, the thiobacilli slowly convert the sulphur into sulphuric acid. The acid then acts on the rock phosphate, changing it into a soluble product resembling superphosphate and gradually releasing sulphur and phosphorus for plant growth.

Biosuper is essentially a slow acting, long term fertiliser. Where a quick response is wanted, for example during pasture establishment, superphosphate is better. But biosuper could provide a reasonable alternative to superphosphate in northern Australia in those situation where it is intended to apply large amounts of fertiliser at infrequent intervals. Field trials are now being carried out in the Northern Territory to test the value of biosuper on rice, sorghum, and Townsville lucerne pastures. Biosuper might have advantages over superphosphate on certain sandy soils where phosphorus is easily dissolved and washed away, and on lateritic soils where phosphorus tends to become fixed in the soil and unavailable to plants.

speech.para: The latter two circumstances apply to a great degree in my own State of Western Australia., where we have sandy soils and lateritic soils. Considerable economic advantages could be achieved by the use of biosuper. I happen to know that the work on biosuper was very nearly abandoned because the Commonwealth decided that the bounty would not be paid on rock phosphate. Fortunately, I had the opportunity of intervening in this matter and the CSIRO decided to go ahead with experiments in the Northern Territory. We do not know how successful biosuper will be until the results of those experiements are evaluated. But there is a very good probability that this new use of rock phosphate with sulphur could confer considerable benefits, particularly in areas where the use of superphosphate has some difficulties because of its high degree of solubility. Another advantage is that there is a possibility of varying the phosphorus-sulphur ratio, which is highly necessary in some of our soils.

This leads me again to a matter which greatly concerns me. Recent work in Western Australia indicates there is an extreme probability that sulphur is a factor in the estrogenic composition of our subterranean clovers and that a lot of the benefits which have been derived from the use of ordinary superphosphate are largely due to the use of sulphur. A farmer who is a neighbour of mine is a graduate in agriculture. He was formerly an officer of the State Department of Agriculture. This man tried to buy a quantity of elemental sulphur from the fertiliser companies for experimental purposes. The only type he could buy was the finely ground sulphur that is used as a fungicide for dusting plants. He was charged a price in excess of $100 a ton for this sulphur, which - with due apologies to the Minister - costs $47 a ton landed in Australia according to the latest information 1 have received.

Vast quantities of this type of elemental sulphur are used in New Zealand for agricultural purposes. I have seen quantities of up to 4 cwt to 1 ton mixed with superphosphate and used on soils in the south island of New Zealand which are very deficient in sulphur, lt appears that we will soon have to use sulphur in similar quantities in the south west of Western Australia. 1 trust that in protecting the welfare and interests of the primary producer the Government will ensure that these essential elements in fertilisers are made available at reasonable prices, nol extortionate prices, and that there wil! be no bar to their ready purchase by those who want to use them. I am taking the opportunity of this debate to introduce matters which 1 consider have a bearing on the use of superphosphate. If we are to subsidise superphosphate it is important to ensure that it is used economically and that it is not being used where sulphur or some other element should be used. With those observations, 1 again commend the Government for increasing the bounty on superphosphate. I believe that the industry needs the assist;) nee at this time.

talk.start.para: - in reply - I thank Senator Wilkinson, who spoke on behalf of the Opposition, and Senator Prowse, for their interesting remarks. Firstly. I wish to reply to some of the queries raised by those honourable senators. Senator Wilkinson said that the Government should ensure that the benefit of the bounty is passed on to the farmer. The Government is well aware of the need lo ensure that this will be done. Senator Prowse indicated that it was the responsibility of the Department of Customs and Excise to ensure that any bounty on superphosphate is passed on to the user and is not gobbled up before it gets to him. I am well aware of my responsibilities to ensure that the bounty is passed on intact for the benefit of all users. 1 should mention that officers of my Department recently examined the manufacturing costs at all Australian fertiliser manufacturers, r understand that a full report will be available to me soon. I assure honourable senators that I shall take appropriate action if the price variations of the manufacturers are such as would suggest that any portion of the bounty is not being passed on to the user.

speech.para: The increase in the bounty from $6 to $8 a ton of standard superphosphate will increase the Government's commitment by $13m to a total of $37m this year. This is a considerable sum. But the Government realises that the farmers need this bounty because of increased costs and has decided that the taxpayers of Australia should contribute a little more than they have been contributing in the past towards the cost of superphosphate. Senator Prowse raised one or two very interesting points. He said that the triple superphosphate that I mentioned in my second reading speech was in actual fact not available to the primary producers al the present time.

talk.start.para: - I pointed out that it was available but it was misdescribed.
- We have not any information as to whether it is available at the present time.
- The Government has paid bounty on it, so the Minister must know.

- I would like to tell the honourable senator that double super can be from 35% to 40% PL,05 and triple super is from 444% to 50% P..0-. The terms as used commercially are loose when compared with the ho un tv payment Which, in relation to other than standard superphosphate, is based on the P.,0.-, or phosphorous pentoxide content. The bounty payment is $40 per ton of P»Os, and the Department polices the P2O5 content of the various products. The higher concentrates of superphosphate are likely to be used more in the future than previously because there is a trend in Australia to the use of the more sophisticated fertiliser compounds such as ammonium phosphates. Double super is sold by Australian Fertilisers Ltd and Greenleaf Fertiliers Ltd. Triple super is sold by Imperial Chemical Industries of Australia and New Zealand Ltd and ACF arid Shirley's Fertilisers Pty Ltd.
- The Minister now knows that the Government pays it.

- 1 am sorry. I think the farmers of Australia should be aware of the P2O0 content of the product they are buying, regardless of whether it is described commercially as double or triple super, for they received the bounty only on the basis of the actual P.,On content of the super.

speech.para: Senator Prowsealso spoke of rock phosphate. The Commonwealth's decision not to pay bounty on rock phosphate was made after careful consideration of the problem. The 20th annual report of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation will be examined. The use of biosuper is still in the experimental stage, but this development will be kept under review to determine its economic application. In his most interesting speech, Senator Prowse mentioned that rock phosphate could be used in the development of our pastures in the north of Australia particularly if the sulphur additive that has been discovered by CSIRO, is added to make the phosphate content of the rock available more quickly to plants in those areas.

I am sure the honourable senators will also bc pleased to know that, apart from this new discovery of biosuper, as we cal'l it, a company known as Broken Hill South Ltd has discovered huge deposits of rock phosphate in the north of Australia adjacent to Cloncurry. From memory. I think that the tonnage proven to date in two or three of these major deposits that have been discovered and tested indicates that there is available within those areas 1,300,000,000 tons of ore with a phosphoric content of 18% and more. This is of tremendous value to Australia particularly when we realise, as has been pointed out by Senator Prowse, the great advantage that biosuper will1 have in the development of our pastures in the north of Australia. 1 point out that with the use of superphosphate and Townsville lucerne the development companies operating in the high rainfall areas of northern Australia are able to increase the carrying capacity of the land from 1 beast to 100 acres to 1 beast to 2 or 3 acres. We can appreciate, therefore, the tremendous development that can take place in areas such as Cape York Peninsular, which is about the same size as Victoria, and which has a rainfall of between 40 and 50 inches a year, if adequate transport facilities are provided to make available at a reasonable price for the improvement of our pastures these new phosphates that have been discovered.

Senator Prowsealso referred to the effect of trace elements on the soil. He explained how large acreages throughout Australia have been transformed by the use of trace elements. Most of our trace elements, of course, are used in conjunction with superphosphate. He also mentioned the findings in Western Australia resulting from experiments with the use of sulphur and its effect on the fertility of breeding ewes in certain pastures over there. He also told us of the terrific improvement of some of our land that can result from the use of sulphur.

He also pointed out that many farmers were top dressing their pastures far too early and as a result were losing up to 50% of the value of their superphosphate. He spoke, too, about bulk transport. Realising its responsibilities, the Government has once more come to the assistance of producers, particularly those in the agricultural areas of Australia, by increasing this bounty on superphosphate from $6 a ton to S8 a ton. 1 thank the members of the Opposition for agreeing to our proposals, and in particular I thank Senator Wilkinson and Senator Prowse for their interesting contributions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through ils remaining stages without amendment or debate.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 12 November (vide page 1878), on motion by Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: - The main purpose of the Bill now before the Senate is to amend the War Service Homes Act to increase the amount of the maximum loan under the war service homes scheme from $7,000 to $8,000. This Bill is typical of the Government's general approach to housing - it gives too little and gives it too late. As I develop my speech I will endeavour to point out to the Senate how the Government has allowed the amount available under the Act to slide back gradually until now the amount which a prospective purchaser has to find by way of deposit, second mortgage and so on has increased greatly.

speech.para: With the exception of a couple of minor amendments which I shall mention later, the Act was last amended in 1962. Early in her speech the Minister for Housing (Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin) referred to that aspect when she said that the War Service Homes Act had been in operation since 1918 and that it had not been amended since 1962. I mentioned a couple of minor amendments. One was made under the National Debt Sinking Fund Act 1966, which had no bearing on the amount of loan under the Act, and the other was made under the Statute Law Revision (Decimal

Currency) Act 1966. Therefore it is 6 years since we have had an opportunity to look at the War Service Homes Act. As I have said, the loan of $7,000 has been in force since 1962 and the Government's failure to increase it has caused the gap between the cost of a home and the amount of the loan to widen. That reinforces my statement that the Government gives too little and gives it too late.

I think we should consider the 1967-68 report of the Director of War Service Homes. Appendix L to the report comprises a table which shows the considerable increase that has occurred in the cost of homes over a period of 10 years. I do not wish to weary the Senate by reciting all the figures but I think some of them should be quoted. For example, in 1958-59 the Commonwealth average cost of a home - that is, a dwelling house and land - was $7,608. In 1961-62 the cost had increased to $8,481. In 1965-66 it was $10,643 and in 1967-68 it was $11,487. I think that those figures indicate the tremendous increase that has occurred. Over 10 years it has amounted to $3,879. With the concurrence of honourable senators and so that no-one will be misled, I incorporate appendix L of the report in Hansard.

YEAR SINCE t JULY 1958

speech.para: Those tables indicate that the amount which the Government proposes to lend under this Act for the purchase of a home is insufficient.

It is pleasing to note, as the Minister said, that the legislation will have been in existence for 50 years in March next year. Since its enactment a considerable number of people have been assisted but it is noticeable also that a considerable number of applications have been made which have not been satisfied. Again I refer to the 1967-68 report of the Director of War Service Homes and turn to appendix G where we find that the number of applications received from the inception of the Act until 30th June 1968 was 517,488. If we subtract the number of applications approved from the number lodged we find that 221,179 have not been approved and that in respect of that number no assistance has been given.

I do not know why such a large number of applications has been rejected. I should like the Minister to explain why there is that number of rejections. I am of the opinion that some people might not have continued with their applications, but nevertheless I feel that some explanation is necessary. I indicate to the Minister and to the Senate that in Committee we will be moving amendments to the Bill.

I have shown to the Senate that there has been a considerable increase in the cost of homes and in the cost of land, and that the amount which the Government is proposing to make available under the Act is insufficient to cover, or even to approach closely, the cost of a home and land. In 1951 or 1952 the amount made available for a war service home was in excess of the average cost of a home. Although the $200 or so which was not required was not made available to an applicant, the money was nevertheless there and could be made available if the cost of a home exceeded the average cost. Appendix L of the 1967-68 annual1 report of the Director of War Service Homes shows that over a period of years there has been a considerable variation in the prices of houses from State to State. Possibly this would be brought about by a number of reasons. In 1967-68 the cost of a home and land in New South Wales was SI 1,388; in Victoria it was $12,102; in Queensland it was $10,665; in South Australia it was $10,427; in Western Australia it was $1 1,705; in Tasmania it was $10,031; and in the Australian Capital Territory, strangely enough, it was $13,161 - the highest of all1. The average for the Commonwealth was $1 1,487.

talk.start.para: - Do those figures relate to homes of all types?

- That is not revealed in the War Service Homes Division report for 1967-68, but I rather expect that it would be for houses of all types. 1 can find no indication in the report as to whether it includes all types of houses or whether specific types only are included. Nevertheless, I suspect that all types would be included in those figures. Perhaps the Minister will be able to clarify this and a number of other points when she replies to the debate.

speech.para: It is noticeable that the number of applications for loans for houses under the War Service Homes Act has declined considerably over the past few years. From page 1 of the report we find that in 1966-67 there were 10,302 applications for loans, of which only 9,754 were approved. The table on page 1 of the report shows that in 1966-67 the total number of applicants assisted was 9,115 and that in 1967-68 the number had decreased to 7,034. That is another matter on which I should like clarification from the Minister. I should like her to explain why an application is not approved in the case of a single person or a person who has been divorced. Let us consider the case of a married man who has a family, possibly with children of school age or younger, who for some reason finds that he is in the divorce court, perhaps through no fault of his own. He has to provide a home for his children. In every other way he qualifies for assistance under the Act, but because he is a divorced person he is disqualified from receiving benefit under the Act. Why should this be? I suggest that any person, man or woman, who has volunteered to go overseas and serve on behalf of his country should be eligible on return to Australia to qualify for a loan under the War Service Homes Act. A divorce should not debar him from qualifying for benefit. There are a number of these matters which I feel that the Minister should clarify to the Senate in her reply. 1 refer next to second assistance under the war service homes legislation. I state at the outset that the Minister has been very good to me in respect of second assistance under the Act, but I refer generally to the provisions of the Bill. 1 have had occasion to fake up matters such as this with the Minister. 1 might say that I have had some success with the Minister, for which I am very thankful and for which the person concerned was very thankful. Even though the Minister was of great assistance to me in particular oases there do appear to be some anomalies in this Act. 1 refer to the situation where a person who is in possession of a war service home suffers a. breakdown in health and transfers from one district to another or from one State to another for medical treatment or because it is more suitable to his health to live elsewhere.

Perhaps another case which could be cited is that of a person who is transferred in employment from district to district or State to State. These are things which warrant further consideration by the Government of second assistance. A person who purchased a home under this Act in the early 1950s or the early 1960s would not have it paid off by any means, but he would have quite an equity. The War Services Homes Division could not lose, in my opinion, if second assistance were granted to such a person when the original home was sold. The additional assistance would go towards the purchase of the new home. An increase in the grant would be necessary because of the increase in costs from year to year. Some of these things should be brought out, and I sincerely hope that the Minister will deal with them in her reply.

She did say in her second reading speech that under the Act, which has been in operation for almost 50 years, approximately 300,000 eligible persons became home owners, as she put it. But they would not all bc home owners; many of them would only be purchasing homes. This is not a particularly good record because it averages out at approximately 600 homes per year. All of these homes would be built in the six States and the Territories - the legislation has been extended to Papua and New Guinea and, T think, to Norfolk Island - so ten States and Territories have shared in the allocations under this Act. Therefore, not a great number of homes has been built. One would expect that there would have been considerably more applications made and more applications approved than there have been under this Act. I shall leave it at that, and 1 sincerely hope the Minister can give me answers to most of the points I have raised.

talk.start.para: - I rise to support the Bill and note that the main provision is le increase the loan for war service homes from $7,000 to $8,000. Before speaking on the advantages of this proposal, I am delighted that the Minister for Housing (Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin) and the Government have seen their way clear to amend the Act to include land under leasehold and under conditional purchase. This is by an amendment to section 4 of the Act. For some time I have been concerned at the exclusion of farmers - particularly those in the developing areas of Western Australia - who purchase land under what i.> known as the conditional purchase system and who have not been eligible for a loan under the War Service Homes Act. By a widening of the definition of a holding under section 4 of the Act they are now, as 1 understand it, to be included. This will be a tremendous advantage to many of these people. The construction of homes in many of these areas has been a problem, lt is a problem for a young person with a young family who is endeavouring to develop land if he has to use of substantial portion of his financial resources to build some type of home. By widening the definition of a holding to include both leasehold and conditional purchase the Government has recognised this problem. 1 am sure it will be greeted with much acclaim by many people who have been adversely affected in the past.

speech.para: There has been - and will be, as I understand, by a foreshadowed amendment in the Committee - some criticism of the maximum amount of the loan. I believe it is always an advantage to be in opposition because when in opposition one need not show a great regard for the taxpayer, lt must always be remembered that there are limits to the burden that can be placed upon him. I remember that the Opposition today fought a proposal for an increase in sales tax to raise more revenue for the Commonwealth, and therefore sought to decrease the amount of revenue to be obtained by the Commonwealth. 1 remember that honourable senators opposite criticised the Budget on the ground that it did not take sufficient account of social welfare, and on many other matters - as is their right - urged that the Government spend more money here and more money there, decrease taxation here and decrease taxation there. One must regard some of these attempts - such as the one which is being foreshadowed - as somewhat irresponsible. 1 do not say this in any nasty way, but it does not show due regard for the budgetary position, nor does it show due regard for the taxpayers of Australia.

There have been, since the inception of this scheme some 50 years ago, continual increases in the amount of the loan. It may be that these have not always kept up with the increases in costs of land and buildings, and I do not know whether it was ever intended that they should. But it is rather interesting when we hear criticism of the Government in this regard in a very well reasoned and moderate speech by Senator Poke to take into account two facts. The first fact is that the average loan applied for and granted over the last 12 months has been under the maximum of $7,000. In fact, it has been about $6,800. That means that a great number of the applicants have not required the full amount of the loan. It is also interesting to note that, on the basis of a maximum loan of $7,000, only 17% of eligible applicants have sought approval to raise secondary finance to supplement their war service homes loans. If these figures mean anything, they mean that there is not tremendous hardship on those people who have been seeking these loans. The figures would seem to justify the Government's view that by raising the limit to $8,000 it will satisfy the great majority of applicants.

It is also good for us to take into account the fact that since the inception of this scheme about 50 years ago, as Senator Poke mentioned and as the Minister mentioned in her second reading speech, in round figures about 300,000 ex-servicemen have benefited from it. Senator Poke pointed out that the number of applicants was well in excess of 500,000 and sought information as to why so many applications apparently have been rejected. I think he admitted that a substantial number of applicants did not go on with their applications for a great number of reasons. Nevertheless the record is a pretty substantial one.

Ever since the inception of this scheme it has been the custom for the maximum lending limit under it and the maximum lending limit of the Commonwealth Savings Bank to be the same. No doubt there are very sound reasons for that. It is all very well to speak of increasing the war service homes loan to $X - whatever figure is mentioned in the Labor Opposition's proposed amendment. But we must always pay due regard to the capacity of the borrower to meet his commitment and to the fact that if we increase the loan the main effect may be to increase the purchase price of both land and buildings rather than to produce more homes or to assist eligible ex-servicemen. That point cannot be completely disregarded. Indeed, I believe that it is a very strong argument. An increase in the maximum loan to $X, without paying due regard to the ceiling of bank loans - whether they be Commonwealth Savings Bank loans or other loans - could well have the effect of forcing up the price of homes and, in so doing, disadvantaging other members of the community. Due regard must be paid to that point. I understand that the Opposition intends to move for a greater increase in the maximum loan. But the Government has a responsibility to see that other sections of the community are not disadvantaged.

A matter that has not been given due recognition is the very favourable rate of interest that is charged. When the scheme was first implemented the rate of interest was 34% and the bond rate was 3i%. Therefore, it was i% above the ruling bond rate. Today the rate of interest is still 3i%, but the bond rate is in the vicinity of 54% or 5*%. So, if the initial relationship had been continued the rate of interest on war service homes loans today would be in the vicinity of 6%. But for ail these years it has been unchanged. 1 think it is the lowest interest rate charged in Australia. I do not think we can disregard the great advantage that this low interest rate gives to ex-servicemen who borrow under the War Service Homes Act.

The second point that we have to consider is the long term of the loans. It is up to 45 years for ex-servicemen and 50 years for widows. I do not point to this because I have any quarrel with it. Indeed, 1 support it. I. believe that ex-servicemen are entitled to these benefits. In any criticism that is made of the Act and the present proposal, due regard must be paid to the many advantages that are available to ex-servicemen under the Act at present.

It is important for a government always to ensure that the money made available does not exceed the resources available. I made that point earlier. If due regard is not paid to that factor, one inevitable effect will be to force up prices, and any advantage that may accrue from an increase in the amount of the loan will soon be lost. This is always a nice matter of judgment. In the Government's judgment an increase of $1,000 in the maximum loan is all that the market and the budgetary position of the Commonwealth can bear. If we increase the amount of the loan still further, either the budgetary position will be affected and the Australian taxpayers will be asked to shoulder a heavier burden or a limit will be placed on the number of applicants who are able to benefit from this scheme. For my part, I would far sooner see a larger number of applicants benefiting from the available resources than a smaller number of applicants benefiting from increased loans.

Taking into account all these factors, I believe that the Bill meets the situation. It pays due regard to some increases in costs. It pays due regard to the dangers of increasing costs. It will prove of considerable benefit to those ex-servicemen who, because of their service, are entitled to receive benefits under this Act. I compliment the Minister, whose sincerity, hard work and understanding have been of great assistance in the administration of the Act. We all can find fault with various aspects of the administration. I was very pleased to hear Senator Poke pay a generous tribute to the Minister who, whenever she can do so within the limits of her powers, goes out of her way to assist those in need. The Government should continue to examine the Act in order to close loopholes and to overcome anomalies which occur from time to time. I agree that it is very difficult to overcome the anomalies completely but we should never believe that the Act is perfect. We should continue to improve it so that the best possible help can be provided for ex-servicemen eligible for assistance under the Act. I support the legislation, Mr President, and hope it has a speedy passage.

talk.start.para: - I wish to speak only briefly about the War Service Homes Act and the amending Bill we are now debating. I believe the Bill is inadequate in one very important respect. The inadequacy is not the subject of a proposed amendment on the part of the Opposition but I think I should refer to it while supporting the remarks made by Senator Poke. The matter 1 raise has been referred to me by a number of British ex-servicemen and concerns the fact that they are not eligible for the same benefits under the War Service Homes Act as are Australian ex-servicemen.

speech.para: L believe this probably derives from the fact that the War Service Homes Act is under the jurisdiction of the Department of Housing. In saying that, 1 cast no aspersions on the Minister for Housing (Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin), the officers of her Department, or her predecessors. However, it seems to me - and I am sure a number of other honourable senators agree - that it would be more logical if the War Service Homes Act were administered by the Repatriation Department. The fact that the dwellings occupied by recipients of benefits under the Act are houses, and therefore should be dealt with by the Department of Housing, is not an argument of substance. After all. other benefits available for ex- servicemen are subject to the administration of Ministers of other Departments. Health benefits available to ex-servicemen are administered by the Repatriation Department and not by the Department of Health. General matters of social welfare affecting ex-servicemen normally are handled by the Minister for Social Services and his Department and not by the Minister for Repatriation and the Repatriation Department. I am not criticising the Government, the Minister, or the officers of her Department, but there seems to me to be logic in having the administration of war service homes in the hands of the Repatriation Department and the Minister for Repatriation rather than in the hands of the Minister for Housing. Senator Rae is nodding his head.

talk.start.para: - I am shaking my head.

- I see. It seems to me that there are very strong reasons for suggesting that all benefits available to cx-servicemen should be dealt with by one department rather than having the bulk of the benefits dealt with by the Repatriation Department and one specific benefit, namely that relating to housing, dealt with by the Department of Housing.

speech.para: I do not wish to dwell on this matter. I want to refer to the fact that benefits associated with war service homes for Australian ex-servicemen are not available to British ex-servicemen. I know there are reciprocal agreements between the Australian and British governments. I am not saying that there is any reason to believe that successive Australian governments have been any less generous in the reciprocal undertakings they have entered into than have the British governments. I would go further, in fact, and say that not only should these benefits that are available to Australian ex-servicemen be available to British ex-servicemen but also that they should be available to ex-servicemen of countries which were allies to Australia in all wars in which we have been engaged.

talk.start.para: - Such as (he South Vietnamese?

- For that matter, yes. Senator Little has suggested that the benefits should be available to the South Vietnamese. I agree. Whether we approve of a particular war. ex-servicemen from countries which have been allied with Australia and who have settled in Australia should be entitled to the same benefits as Australian ex-servicemen. I do not submit this point for consideration because I am critical of the approach of any Australian government to any of the reciprocal arrangements made with British governments. I realise that there are some concessions available to British ex-servicemen. One is. that if a British ex-serviceman was resident in Australia before joining the British armed forces, he is eligible to receive benefits such as those available under the war service homes scheme. However, such men are not eligible to receive these benefits if they were not resident in Australia before joining the British armed forces.

speech.para: Possibly the main reason 1 have for making this suggestion, apart from the humanitarian aspect, is that I believe that any person who has served as an ally of the Australians and has fought in the same conflict, should be regarded in the same way as an Australian ex-serviceman who served in that conflict. I am also looking at this matter from the point of view of the desirability of encouraging migration to Australia, lt has been put to me that there is a number of British ex-servicemen living in Australia who fought as allies during the Second World War. They have settled in Australia yet find they are not eligible to receive the same benefits in respect of war service homes as are their fellow allied and Commonwealth soldiers, the Australians.

No amendment has been submitted by the Opposition along these lines but I think it is a matter which should be considered in due course by the Government. On the face of it, it seems to me that there is an argument for British ex-servicemen, in particular and allied ex-servicemen in general, to be eligible for the benefits available to Australian ex-servicemen. Even if some reciprocal arrangements were entered into in the past it strikes me that this is something of an anomaly. We are encouraging migrants to come to Australia. Some of the people who have come here served in alliance with the Australian forces during the war, yet find they are discriminated against in relation to the benefits available to people who served in the Australian armed forces. This is the position even though these migrants who formerly served in alliance with our forces have now become Australian citizens.

talk.start.para: - This Bill proposes to amend the War Service Homes Act. The Opposition approves of the Bill in principle, and of the reassessment of the situation regarding homes for eligible ex-servicemen who served in the numerous wars in which we have been engaged in the last SO years. Perhaps it is a reflection on the Australian nation that so many eligible ex-servicemen who have applied for assistance under the War Services Homes Act have not been able to obtain it. In my view, many of the restrictions placed on ex-servicemen have been harsh. The definition of 'Australian soldier' is discriminatory and is becoming even more so because of the changing nature of war. In the past, an Australian soldier was. by tradition, a volunteer. He travelled overseas and took part in foreign wars because Australia was a member of the British Empire and, later, a member of the British Commonwealth of Nations. We asked our men to leave their homeland and go into the heat and burden of the battle in a foreign land. As a reward for their services we offer them something which, in any civilized society, should be available to every citizen; that is a home of average quality which a man may call his own and in which he can have his family about him - a home that adds to his status and pride in the community.

speech.para: But some restrictions have been placed on ex-servicemen, through no fault of their own. I refer to ex-servicemen who have been provident enough to save, either through deferred pay or by other methods, and have bought homes. They have entered into arrangements with private institutions, either banks or other financing organisations. This move has proved to be a barrier to their obtaining their entitlement of access to money at a cheap rate of interest as is available to other ex-servicemen.

I know of many cases of ex-servicemen who were more or less forced through frustration, because of the long delays that have been inherent in and traditional with the War Service Homes Division - not through any fault of the officers but through Government policy in restricting the amount of funds available - to find an alternative way to finance the purchase of a home. By taking the initiative themselves I believe they earn an entitlement to a later reward when funds become available to take over their existing mortgages. They should be able to enjoy the great benefit of obtaining low interest money for housing.

Today the cost of housing is such that to borrow money at current rates of interest through financing organisations makes the provision of a home a very great burden on the average wage or salary earner. Interest up to 7% is charged on first mortgages, and extortionate rates are charged by institutions that lend money on second mortgages. I believe that the War Service Homes Division should be obliged to look after the cases of ex-servicemen who have taken the initiative to purchase homes so that they may receive the benefits of the low interest rates that are available to their colleagues who are eligible for a war service home loan. The War Service Homes Division should be widening its horizons by reinvesting the repayments that have accumulated over the years since the scheme has been in operation. The objective should be to provide for people who have played their part in the Services in offering themselves for the defence of this country. Because of a policy operating at that time, some of them were not chosen to go overseas, despite the fact that they had signed on to serve overseas if called upon to do so. They should be automatically entitled to a war service home loan.

I do not think we can be self-satisfied in our attitude towards housing until money at low interest rates is available to every young married couple wishing to set up their own home. Outside the war service homes scheme there is a very limited incentive of home savings grants. A small subsidy is made available to young married people, but they are encouraged then to become involved in enormous expense as a consequence of modern financing methods. As I said earlier, they become involved in the payment of interest rates of up to 7% on first mortgages and up to 10% or 12% on second mortgages. Millstones are placed around their necks for periods of 40 years or more. Over that time they suffer the consequences of accepting the social responsibility to accommodate their young families in homes and must carry a great burden over a long period.

This legislation deals only with the exservicemen in the community. The investment of the nation in the scheme over the years is coming back in the form of repayments. 1 believe that all this money should be redirected to the provision of homes for Australian soldiers, and in that category I would include every man who signs up to participate in the defence of his country, within or without, provided that if his services are needed overseas, he will readily submit himself to serve in any theatre of war. He should be able to be as proud as any other soldier for having offered his services for the defence of his country.

talk.start.para: - Does that include the permanent forces?
- Yes, and national servicemen and members of the Citizen Military Forces who sign up for a period of 5 years and can be called upon to serve anywhere in an emergency.
- How many people are involved in the proposed scheme?
- As I see it, eventually the nation will take on the responsibility of financing homes for all our citizens.
- But how many people are involved in the proposed amendment?

- I do not have the figures readily available. Last year about 6,700 applications were approved but I do not have available at the moment figures that would help me to calculate the number requested by the Minister.
- Will the honourable senator put forward a plan to finance the scheme?

- I am advocating that a plan should be worked out to make such a scheme possible. I would like to see the actuaries equate the funds that are coming in as repayments over a long period of years to the amounts required to finance and service a scheme to provide homes for all people who have volunteered or are called up for service in the defence of their country.

talk.start.para: - I wish to raise a matter to which I referred in question time this morning and that is the absence of proper medical facilities and a qualified medical practitioner on Groote Eylandt. Although it may not appear on the record, I indicated to the Minister representing the Minister for Health (Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin) that I would raise this matter on the adjournment tonight. I notice that the Minister is in attendance. I recollect that I spoke on this subject in the Senate about 12 months ago. lt has also been taken up by the residents of Groote Eylandt with the Commonwealth authorities

speech.para: The residents of Groote Eylandt are complaining bitterly that although the island has a population of over 1,000 and although large mining activities are being conducted they do not have proper medical facilities or a qualified medical practitioner. During the week I received a petition from the residents of Groote Eylandt. It was forwarded to me by Mr Paddy Carroll, who is Secretary of the North Australian Workers Union. He said that he had been asked by the residents of Groote Eylandt to forward this petition to me. Mr President, I shall paraphrase some of the language used in his letter to make it a little more acceptable to the Senate. He said that the Minister for Health (Dr Forbes) had visited Groote Eylandt some time ago with the Prime Minister (Mr Gorton) and had made a hasty inspection but did not approach the residents about any complaints. The letter adds:

quote.para: We have made several approaches to the Health Department in Darwin, however what Canberra says is it.

speech.para: Apparently he meant that the real determination was made in Canberra and not in Darwin. He went on to say that the latest information received was that a fully manned hospital would be built at Gove

Peninsula, which is about 100 miles north of Groote Eylandt, and that patients would be flown to that hospital for treatment if an aircraft was available. He said that this arrangement was quite unacceptable to the residents of the island. The residents of the island have prepared a petition which I shall read to the Senate. It is not in a form that could strictly be received by the Senate under the Standing Orders. The petition reads:

quote.para: We the undersigned residents of Alyangula wish to protest strongly against the Government's policy in relation to the lack of medical facilities and qualified practitioners of Groote Eylandt.

Although the Minister of Health, Dr Forbes, has stated, in the Senate that we are in a position to call on quarantine doctors when they are on the island to inspect ships, we can rest assured that this is not the case at all. Most of these doctors come and go in a charter plane on the same day, without even seeing the medical centre, let alone seeing patients.
We emphatically believe that the death of Mr Tony Rainsford could have been avoided if a doctor had diagnosed him when he first complained of his condition, which was 2 weeks prior to his death.
By this protestation we wish to make it quite clear that we are not questioning the capabilities of Sister Maher, who is very proficient in her category and a well respected citizen of the community.

talk.start.para: - How many residents are on the island?

- I am not quite sure, but from earlier inquiries T made I think there are over 1,000. The notation I have is that the petition was actually signed by 161 or 162 people. Mr President, I ask for leave of the Senate to table this document. As I have said it does not strictly conform to the Standing Orders relating to petitions but it was forwarded to me as a petition.
- is that the document in which the Leader of the Opposition thought it wise to change some of the phraseology?

- No. If the honourable senator had listened carefully he would have understood that I was then referring to a letter I had received. I indicated that because it contained some rather harsh reflections upon the Government that I would interpolate a little. I have read the petition in its exact terms and I have asked for leave to table it. The people who prepared it do not have access to the documents which would enable them to put a petition in the precise form required under the Standing Orders. The petition is signed by a large number of the residents of the island. 1 think the Senate should receive it.
- Order! There being no objection, leave is granted.

- This is quite a serious matter. The residents of Groote Eylandt, who, as I understand the position, number over 1,000, are entitled to reasonable medical facilities. If one examines the statistics which apply throughout Australia one will see that in the cities there is one doctor to every 1,000 people. Actually, 1 think that the position is a little better than that in the cities. Those who live in isolated areas - and Groote Eylandt is an example - are entitled to the same facilities as those who live in the cities. Groote Eylandt is contributing a good deal to the economy of Australia. Large mining activities are being conducted in the area. The residents are very concerned at the lack of medical facilities and have been making great efforts to obtain them. With a good deal of force they have pointed out - and much the same sort of thing has been said in the Press - that a citizen who was suffering from some complaint died on the island last week because it was a couple of weeks before he could be attended as there is no doctor on the island. I might say that, as I recall it, there is no policeman on the island even though sometimes the difficulties which one might expect in any community do arise. They need one there. These people have been thoroughly neglected by the Commonwealth. Now that the matter has been sent down here, if no attention has been paid to their approaches before, I do ask that the Government listen to them now. They are being reasonable about this man's death. They think it was due to failure to have a doctor on the island. Surely the Commonwealth ought to pay more attention to their complaints than apparently has been paid to them before. They have been an isolated community. It has been very difficult for their voice to be heard in the ivory tower of Canberra and, on their behalf, and I ask that those responsible, if they have not done so before, attend to their complaint now and see that they have the reasonable facilities that ought to be afforded to any group of citizens in Australia in 1968.

[10.41] - When Senator Murphy asked his question this afternoon I felt that it related to a matter which could give rise to very great concern. For that reason, I suggested that it go on notice. I was anxious to get all the information I could for the honourable senator. The honourable senator then indicated that he wished to speak about the matter on the motion for the adjournment of the Senate tonight. I can assure Senator Murphy that I have listened with great interest to the points he has raised. I have received some information but 1 do not think it covers everything that the honourable senator mentioned tonight. However, 1 can assure him that what he has said tonight will be drawn to the notice of the Minister for Health (Dr Forbes).

speech.para: As we all know, Groote Eylandt is a large island in the western half of the Gulf of Carpentaria, close to the eastern coast of Arnhem Land. The information that I have is that the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd has large mining leases on the island and is developing these for the production of manganese. Development started about 1963 and manganese ore has been produced and shipped for approximately 3 years. The Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd maintains a township on the island with a population of approximately 300 people. There is in addition on another part of the island a mission of approximately 700 Aboriginals.

The Department maintains a small hospital at the BHP township with a fully trained sister. The Church Missionary Society has an establishment of two trained sisters at their mission. The island is visited frequently by medical officers from Darwin on routine medical flights. In addition, medical officers visit the island for quarantine purposes and on these occasions see such patients as require to be examined, although routine cases are not usually seen on visits for quarantine purposes. Additional visits are made for special surveys, such as immunisation programmes and the tuberculosis scheme.

For 1968, 5 routine visits were made, 14 visits for quarantine purposes and special visits on three occasions, making a total of 22 visits during the year so far. On all of these visits patients were actually seen. On the routine visits the medical officer stays overnight. In addition there is a 24 hour wireless service available 7 days a week for emergencies, with two routine sessions connected to Darwin each week day at 8.30 and 1415 hours. The recent death - I presume this is the death to which Senator Murphy referred - was of a patient with a long history of epigastric pain and vomiting which was first diagnosed when he was at Victoria River Downs Station. The medical officer who arrived at Groote Eylandt at 10.15 a.m. on Tuesday 29th October examined the patient whose condition did not give rise to concern. Death occurred after sudden deterioration at approximately 12 hours later on the same night whilst the doctor was in attendance. Whilst it is recognised that people in isolated areas deserve special consideration, it is not believed that the amount of work at Groote Eylandt would keep a medical officer fully occupied, and under these circumstances it is considered that there would be difficulty in retaining a medical officer on the island when he would not be able to fully employ his professional knowledge.

talk.start.para: - But what about the people?

- I have given the information that has been supplied to me. I repeat what I said earlier: I think the honourable senator has raised more points tonight than are covered by the information which has been supplied by my colleague, the Minister for Health. Because of the situation which the honourable senator has put before us tonight, 1 assure him that I shall take the matter up with the Minister and bring to his notice the extra points raised.

speech.para: Senator MCCLELLAND(New South Wales) [10.441 - I take advantage of the motion for the adjournment to refer to a matter-

talk.start.para: - Mr President, may I say something further on this matter before the next matter is dealt with?
- The Minister has replied. However, the honourable senator can raise the subject at a later stage.

- I wish to refer to an answer given to me today by the Minister representing the Postmaster-General (Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin) in reply to a question I had placed on notice on 23rd October last. I suggest that this Government, or at least its instrumentality, the Australian Broadcasting Control Board, has been and is giving preferential treatment, or most favoured nation treatment to the Ansett television station <at the expense of the encouragement of Australian productions for television purposes.

speech.para: For some time past, I and a number of my colleagues on this side of the chamber, as well as a small minority on the Government side, have been advocates of the encouragement of the production of Australian films for television purposes. Because of the Government's inertia or the lethargy of the Australian Broadcasting Control Board, I feel that I have <a public responsibility to raise the subject of an answer that I received from the Minister representing the Postmaster-General today to a question that I placed on notice on 23rd October last.

At the outset, let me refer to a recommendation made by the Australian Broadcasting Control Board to the then PostmasterGeneral, on 11th February 1963 in a report by the Australian Broadcasting Control Board on an application for a licence for a commercial television station in the Melbourne area when a company known as Austerama Television Pty Ltd, commonly known as the Ansett television company, was recommended by the Australian Broadcasting Control Board to be given a licence for the promotion of Channel 0 in Melbourne.
On 11th February 1963, the Australian Broadcasting Control Board, in recommending that the licence be given to Austerama Television Pty Ltd, had this to say, amongst other things:

quote.para: We have considered also another aspect of this matter. The airline operations of Ansett Transport Industries Ltd are not only strictly regulated under the laws of the Commonwealth but as a result of the Civil Aviation Agreements the successful operation of the company's airline is in effect guaranteed by the Commonwealth for a lengthy period. We have considered whether a company with such a privileged position under the airlines legislation should also be enabled to operate a commercial television station by the grant of a licence under the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942-1960 since it is clear that the number of such licences must be strictly limited and they confer valuable privileges. This point was not clearly raised or fully argued before us: we have given it careful consideration and, in our opinion, this applicant is not disqualified on this ground. While we do- not think that the contention of the applicant that television is a logical extension of its transport operations is justified in the terms in which it was put forward by Mr Ansett in evidence, it seems to be fairly claimed that the very large service industry which is carried on by Ansett Transport Industries is not entirely dissimilar to a television service in the sense that experience in conducting public services is an essential qualification for each. We are satisfied that the real case for this applicant lies in its successful establishment of a record of ability, energy, enthusiasm and material resources, and in its understanding of its public responsibilities.

During the course of the hearing of the application which the Australian Broadcasting Control Board recommended to the Australian Government for acceptance, and so far as the requirements of section 114 of the Broadcasting and Television Act relating to Australian programmes for television were concerned, Austarama Television Pty Ltd stated in its application:
Australian programmes would initially-

speech.para: I emphasise the word 'initially' - occupy 38% (24i hours weekly) of the hours of service, with increases after the first year. Programmes would emphasise Australian characteristics and backgrounds, and would employ Australian talent as far as possible. A one-hour drama series on Sundays would have Australian historical settings. A film unit would be established to make 'walkabout' programmes covering all parts of Australia.

In case anyone doubts the statements I am making, I point out that I am reading from the recommendations dated 11th February 1963 that were submitted by the Australian Broadcasting Control Board to the then Postmaster-General.

Bearing in mind the recommendations made by the Board and the undertakings given to the Board by the applicant, Austarama Television Pty Ltd, in February 1 963, 1 was amazed to find today that despite no application having been made by ATV Melbourne for dispensation from the requirement to provide a certain amount of Australian dramatic programmes, dispensation was granted to that station by the Australian Broadcasting Control Board. I raised this issue by way of a question on notice as long ago as August 1968. It was in the following terms: "Did the Australian Broadcasting Control Board, in August 1966-

Some 2 years and 4 months ago - issue a requirement to all metropolitan commercial television stations that as from 3rd July 1967 they should telecast not less than 2 hours of Australian dramatic programmes between 7 p.m. and 9.40 p.m. during every 28 days statistical period?
The answer given by the Minister representing the Postmaster-General was:

quote.para: Yes; this was one of several requirements for Australian content in programmes.

speech.para: Then I asked:

quote.para: Have all commercial television networks, other than the Ansett network, completely complied with this provision?

speech.para: The Minister replied:

quote.para: The more recently established metropolitan commercial television stations, namely TEN Sydney, ATV Melbourne-

speech.para: I emphasise ATV Melbourne -

quote.para: TVQ Brisbane and SAS Adelaide, have experienced some difficulty in meeting the requirement of the Australian Broadcasting Control Board that not less than 2 hours of Australian drama programmes should be presented between 7 p.m. and 9.30 p.m. during every 28 days statistical period.

speech.para: I emphasise also the difficulties that apparently ATV Melbourne has been experiencing despite the undertaking it gave to the Australian Broadcasting Control Board in its application for a licence as far back as 1.963. The Minister went on:

quote.para: Following special representations by these stations-

speech.para: I take it, as I assume every honourable senator would take it, that this meant each of the four stations - which put forward in detail the financial problems facing the stations, the .Board early this year decided to waive the drama requirement for them until August-September 1968 when the matter would be reviewed.

The Board reviewed the matter once again in August-September 1968. It was indicated in reply to my question on 17th October 1968 that following a further review by the Australian Broadcasting Control Board dispensation from their obligation to comply with the Australian drama requirements would be granted until February 1969. In reply to a question which I had placed on the notice paper the Minister representing the Postmaster-General said:

quote.para: The Board's report-

speech.para: That is the annual report of the Australian Broadcasting Control Board for the year ended 30th October 1968 - indicates that in response to special representations which put forward in detail the financial problems facing four of the more recently established metropolitan television stations the Board, in February 1968, decided to waive temporarily the requirement for them to televise 2 hours of drama each month.

Following that answer and as a result of matters that J and my colleague, Senator Cant, raised in the debate on the estimates for the Postmaster-General's Department, I placed another question on the notice paper on 23rd October 1968. Amongst other things J asked the Minister whether each of the four stations had lodged an individual application or whether a single application was lodged on behalf of all of them. The Minister replied:

quote.para: Individual applications were lodged as follows: TEN Sydney . . . TVQ Brisbane ... SAS Adelaide . . . But the concession was granted on the basis of consideration of the position of the stations concerned as a network, the fourth station of which, ATN' Melbourne-

speech.para: The Ansett station - did not make an individual application.

Here we have the situation in which ATV Melbourne, which in its original application had undertaken to present to the Australian viewing audience a certain content of Australian programmes, a certain proportion of which were to be dramatic in origin, without making an individual application to the Australian Broadcasting Control Board was granted dispensation from the requirement that the Board had laid down to produce a certain amount of Australian dramatic programmes. An excuse that was used by the Minister representing the PostmasterGeneral - perhaps it came from the PostmasterGeneral himself - was that the concession was granted on the basis of a consideration of the stations concerned being part of a network. Although Channels TEN Sydney, TVQ Brisbane and SAS Adelaide each made individual applications for dispensation from the requirements stipulated by the Broadcasting Control Board, no individual application was lodged by ATV Melbourne. But because the other stations had each lodged an application for dispensation ATV Melbourne - Channel O, the Ansett station - automatically was granted a dispensation.

Let us look at the statement made in the Senate on 24th May 1965 by the Minister representing the Postmaster-General when the Broadcasting and Television Act was being amended with respect to the effective control and ownership of television stations. We see that at that time the Minister said, among other things, that one aspect of the matter which required some comment was the proposal to repeal section 16 (3.) (e) of the Act which empowered the Board to regulate the establishment of networks of stations and the making of arrangements by licensees for the provision of programmes or the broadcasting or televising of advertisements. The Minister who introduced the measure in this House at that time on behalf of the Postmaster-General went on to say at page 1133 of Hansard of 24th May 1965:

quote.para: There has always been doubt regarding the application of this provision and it is, in fact, difficult to say precisely just what a network is. A similar difficulty has been experienced in other countries. In these circumstances, it has been considered desirable to repeal this provision in the Act and to provide for the making of regulations in respect of such matters.

speech.para: In the time that has been available to me this afternoon I have gone through the regulations made under the Broadcasting and Television Act, but so far I have not been able to find any regulation which stipulates what a television network is. I suggest to the Government that because station ATV Melbourne - the Ansett station - has received a dispensation with regard to the presentation of Australian programmes, it is being given preferential treatment or, in tariff terms, most favoured nation treatment, by the Government at the expense of the encouragement of Australian programmes for television, and especially at the expense of the encouragement of Australian dramatic programmes. I suggest to the Government and to the Australian Broadcasting Control Board that it is time that all sections of the industry were treated fairly and equitably. It is time that the Government ensured that all people who have been given a television licence are compelled to carry out their obligation to encourage the production of Australian programmes for television, especially in view of the undertaking that the individual applicants made at the time that they applied to the Broadcasting Control Board for a commercial television licence.

talk.start.para: - Lest there be any thought of discourtesy to the honourable senator, I make it clear that the forms of the Senate will not permit a reply from the Minister for Housing (Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin), who represents the Postmaster-General (Mr Hulme) in this chamber, as she has already spoken once during the adjournment debate tonight. She has indicated to me that she will refer to the Australian Broadcasting Control Board and to the Minister the matters which the honourable senator has raised.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.5 p.m.
